thread.title: No jobs, no cash, no future - the state of mind of North East youth, says report

author: Mike Kelly
title: No jobs, no cash, no future - the state of mind of North East youth, says report
text:

The grim findings of a new report have laid bare the sense of despair felt by young people in the North East about their lives. 
It shows they are worried about their finances, their jobs prospects and even their body shapes. 
Around two thirds of those surveyed said recent political events such as Brexit have made them more anxious about life compared to a year ago while 30% felt they had no control over their lives whatesoever. 
The findings come in the latest Prince’s Trust Macquarie Youth Index, which measures happiness and confidence in young people, and reveal that youth wellbeing is at its lowest level since the index was first commissioned in 2010. The Union flag flies alongside the EU flag (Photo: Toby Melville/PA Wire) 
Jonathan Townsend, North Regional Director at The Prince’s Trust said: “This report paints a deeply concerning picture of a generation who feel their ability to shape their own future is slipping away from them. 
“It’s shocking how many feel so desperate about their situation and it is vital that we support them to develop the confidence and coping skills they need to succeed in life.” Read More Newcastle young people are 'prisoners in their homes' due to anxiety says Prince's Trust 
The Youth Index gauges wellbeing across a range of areas, from family life to physical health. 
A shocking one in five think that their life will amount to nothing, no matter how hard they try, while a further 17% say they don’t believe they can change their circumstances if they want to. A sad child (Photo: Handout) 
The report highlights a range of factors that appear to be contributing to this sense of hopelessness in young people across the region. 
For example, 60% feel stressed about their finances, more than half are stressed about body image, while 41% do not feel in control of their job prospects. Read More World Mental Health Day: Young people urged to end stigma over talking about mental health 
Many feel confused, with more than half claiming they don’t know what to believe because they read conflicting things in the media about the economy. 
Meanwhile, over half of young people feel the pressures of getting a job are greater than a year ago, and 35% feel that traditional goals like owning a house or getting a steady job are unrealistic. 
Mr Townsend added: “The single most important thing we can do to empower these young people is to help them into a job, an education course or onto a training programme. 
“Now, more than ever, we must work together to provide the support and opportunities they need to unlock a brighter future.” Like us on Facebook
